node.title: American Chloe Kim wins 2nd straight Olympic gold in women's halfpipe
node.description: She was so far ahead she tried one of here toughest tricks in her third and final run, but fell.

node.title: 'Incredible stuff': History, science and art in the mix for Fiordland expedition
node.description: An expedition into one of Aotearoa's most remote areas has unlocked some long-hidden secrets, and will give Kiwis a glimpse into an unseen past.

node.title: Farmers with asymptomatic Covid-19 may be able to keep working - Minister
node.description: Farmers who test positive for Covid-19 may be able to continue working if they're vaccinated, asymptomatic and not in contact with others, Agriculture Minister Damien O'Connor says. Audio

node.title: Sanford reports strong sales growth for greenshell mussels and salmon
node.description: Seafood company Sanford says it is seeing the start of a post-pandemic recovery, with improved sales driven by strong demand for greenshell mussels and salmon.

node.title: Marathon shearing effort nets $130,000 for charity hospital
node.description: Organisers say they are blown away by the support they received during a shearathon that raised money for the Southland Charity Hospital.

node.title: NT records two COVID-related deaths, with 168 patients now in hospital
node.description: Two women in their 60s with underlying health conditions have died with COVID-19 in the Northern Territory — the first time multiple COVID-related deaths have been reported in one day.

node.title: Police on hand as ticketing of protesters' vehicles begins
node.description: The Wellington police are helping parking wardens to clear blocked roads around Parliament, with about 120 tickets issued so far.

node.title: Lobster exports crawling back up after Covid-19 grips industry sales
node.description: Two years after New Zealand's $300 million rock lobster export industry came to a halt overnight due to the pandemic, harvesters are feeling more optimistic about sales.

node.title: Nathan Chen wins gold at the men’s individual event.
node.description: By Juliet Macur

node.title: Napier's Art Deco Festival to go ahead, but scaled back
node.description: Despite the many event cancellations across the motu due to Omicron, Napier's Art Deco Festival is still going ahead next week, but it will be hugely scaled back.

node.title: Covid-19 update: Record 306 new community cases today
node.description: There are 306 new community cases of Covid-19 in New Zealand today - a new record high - with 216 cases in Auckland alone.

node.title: Teams isolating as Covid-19 scare hits Super Rugby
node.description: Two Super Rugby Pacific teams are isolating in Queenstown due to Covid-19 close contact protocols.

node.title: Man recalls priest taking photos while he was forced to sexually abuse another child
node.description: A man who spent time in a church orphanage as a child has told the Abuse in Care inquiry he was forced by two priests to sexually violate another boy.

node.title: Second Covid-19 case confirmed in Queenstown
node.description: Two confirmed Covid-19 cases in the Queenstown Lakes district are being described as a wake-up call for the community.

node.title: Two Dallas officers charged with assaulting people during 2020 George Floyd protests
node.description: The officers are expected to turn themselves in, officials said.

node.title: Oath Keepers founder Stewart Rhodes returns to court next week
node.description: Rhodes, who is being held in a federal prison facility in Oklahoma, is seeking to remain closer to his Texas-based attorneys, even if he is to remain in pretrial detention.

node.title: Vulcan's half-year profit nearly doubles
node.description: Recently listed steel products company Vulcan has reported a near doubling of its half-year profit on strong demand and sales.

node.title: Cruise ship industry hoping for 2022 return
node.description: The country's cruise ship industry is hopeful it will be returning the waters next summer - or even earlier - but warns it's a long way off before making any final decision.

node.title: Grace Tame received 'threatening' phone call regarding PM's reputation
node.description: Grace Tame says a senior member of an organisation funded by the Australian government asked her not to say anything controversial about Scott Morrison, in a "threatening" phone call while she was…

node.title: Covid-19: Two cases discovered at Gisborne intermediate school
node.description: Two students who go to Ilminister Intermediate, in the Gisborne suburb of Kaiti, have returned positive results.

node.title: Even as Australia's borders reopen, our largest cohort of tourists won't return for some time
node.description: Chinese tourists used to spend three times as much as Americans in Australia, but several factors mean they are unlikely to come back in significant numbers any time soon.

node.title: Bob Saget died from head trauma, family says
node.description: The "Full House" star died last month at the age of 65.

node.title: Phoenix claim third straight win
node.description: Wellington Phoenix knock over Melbourne Victory, claiming their third straight A-League win.

node.title: More Democratic governors ease mask requirements
node.description: The politics around COVID restrictions appear to be changing. "[I]t's time to give people their lives back," tweeted Rep. Sean Maloney.

node.title: Bipartisan group of senators say they have reached a deal on Violence Against Women Act
node.description: Senator Dick Durbin acknowledged they still need more Republican's support to pass it.

node.title: PM tells anti-vaccine mandate protesters outside Parliament to 'move on'
node.description: Jacinda Ardern says "obviously every New Zealander has a right to protest, but there are also rules around what is able to happen on Parliament's forecourt".

node.title: Pelosi, Schumer signal they'd support ban on stock trading for Congress
node.description: Both Democrats and Republicans favor a ban and are working on legislation with stiffer restrictions on lawmakers' portfolios.

node.title: Air patrols and high-tech policing: Inside the plan to keep the Super Bowl safe
node.description: Law enforcement will be on patrol from the air, land and ocean to keep one of the biggest events of the year safe.

node.title: Court process still putting victims' privacy at risk
node.description: There is still no warning on court document request forms to inform victims their addresses could be seen by offenders.

node.title: Protest has the risk of becoming a superspreader event - expert
node.description: A protest on Parliament grounds, which has entered its third day with campers staying overnight, is at risk of becoming a Covid-19 superspreader event, says an epidemiologist. Audio
